pullRequest.body:
Add some general purpose lemmas on lists. The new ext_get?' is intermediate between ext and ext_get, and for consistent naming add an alias ext_get? for ext.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

These lemmas are used in a project on Borel determinacy that may be added to mathlib.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Thank you. I had a look at the style guide already, but my attempts to fix this with a few regexps didn't find all the issues. Now, apart from "hypotheses left of colon" (see above), I tried to fix all the mentioned issues

One more thing: when you're addressed a comment, can you click "resolve conversation"? (If you would still like some opinion on a question, just leave it open. But right now, it's hard to see which is which.) Thanks!

Update: I just did this for most of them.

> (And I'll file a PR to remove the other occurrences.)
Note that I fixed the occurences in this file already in the last commit (to avoid merge conflicts)

> > (And I'll file a PR to remove the other occurrences.)
> > Note that I fixed the occurences in this file already in the last commit (to avoid merge conflicts)

I know! For me, it was easier to fix them all - I added you as a co-author on #11714. (Feel free to tweak how you're mentioned in the PR description.) I hope that's also fine!
Also, please merge master because there is a merge conflict. Let me know if you need help / need me to do it.

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8555829173/job/23444159939)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8556252378/job/23445625234)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8556252378/job/23445624446)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8556252378/job/23445625574)

LGTM
bors merge

Thanks for your contribution and welcome to mathlib!

I gave your PR a first look and have a lot of style comments. (This is perfectly normed for a first PR.) Quite a few things are also copied from the [style guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html); did you get to read that already?

Some issues occur several times - I haven't mentioned them all the time; please also address similar instances below.

Thanks! You're right, the style guide doesn't mention spaces between tactics and their arguments. I think that's an oversight and should be fixed. (And I'll file a PR to remove the other occurrences.)

Just a few more, then I'm out of comments :-)
Thanks, looks good. I still have a few comments.

LGTM
bors merge
Please put a blank line between two theorems. This makes files *so* much easier to read.
Per the style guide, please put the `by` on the previous line, and also put a space after the tactic name (i.e., do `rw [eq_comm]` instead of `rw[eq_comm]` etc.)

About `rw[...]` vs `rw [...]`: I couldn't find this rule in your style guide (although the examples there comply), but just something about spaces after left arrows, and also had to fix this at places in the file not added by this commit. Maybe you should add it?

I would put the conclusion on the same line.
Please put separate tactic calls on different lines: altogether, I'd write this like
```lean
@[simp]
theorem head_replicate {n} {a : α} (h : List.replicate n a ≠ []) : head _ h = a := by
  cases n <;> simp at *
  exfalso
  exact h rfl
Here, the style guide rule "hypotheses left of colon" applies: l₁, l₂ and `∀ n, l₁.get? n = l₂.get? n` should become hypotheses, so the conclusion is only `l₁ = l₂`.
Also, please put a blank line before and after this theorem.

Does "hypotheses left of colon" really apply? The condition "if the proof starts by introducing these variables" of the style guild is not satisfied (although I don't understand the dec_trivial example there)

Good point - you don't explicitly introduce new variables in the beginning, that's right.
I'm quite sure some variables are introduced at least implicitly - I would put the first left of the colon for sure. I just tried it out, the second one also works...

And now that I tried it, it seems that is quite literally the same statement as `List.ext` in `std`.
Another reviewer may comment on this, but I wonder if this lemma should be removed, as it already exists.
Indeed, I added an alias for List.ext to make the naming more consistent with my new ext-Lemma. I also don't know if this should be removed.
I would remove this, and call the next lemma `ext_get?`. That seems consistent with [List.ext_get](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Std/Data/List/Lemmas.html#List.ext_get) to me.

A few comments:
- please put spaces around the colon, i.e. `{x y : List α} : x ++ y = x ↔ y = []`
- in general, writing several tactics on one line is frowned upon (there are exceptions, but this is a good rule of thumb)

Altogether, I'd write this more like
```lean
@[simp]
theorem append_left_cancel_nil_left {x y : List α} : x ++ y = x ↔ y = [] := by
  constructor <;>
  intro h <;>
  apply List.append_cancel_left (as := x) <;>
  all_goals simp [h]
```

This last line is interesting: after the `rcases`, you have two goals.
In such cases, please intend both of them and precede them by a focusing dot · (inserted as \.), like so

```lean
  rcases Nat.lt_or_ge n l₂.length with hn | hn
  · exact h' _ hn
  · simp[List.get?_eq_none.mpr hn, le_trans h hn]
Please use focusing dots to intend goals, not brackets.
Please intend this line and use a focusing dot.

You have a "non-terminal simp" here (the `simp[Nat.le_min] at h` is not closing a goal). These are harder to maintain over time: please replace them by an equivalent `simp only` call: writing `simp?` will tell you which lemmas you need. (This procedure is called "squeezing", for I think just historical reasons: just in case you hear that word and wonder.)
Similarly, the `dsimp` is non-terminal. Please "squeeze" it also, i.e. replace by a `dsimp only` call.
Often, the first version of a proof can be "golfed", i.e. written in a shorter or more concise way. This is such a case: the last lines can be combined into one: `exact hx (List.prefix_nil.mp h)`

Can you write this as two lines, or better, combine into one? Here's a Lean trick: `by simp [h]` creates a proof term again, which you can use in the apply - i.e., writing `apply List.append_cancel_left (as := x) (by simp [h])`.
Then you can replace `apply` by `exact`.
I would put these on two lines. This might be a matter of taste.
Can you put these on different lines?

You can simplify this slightly, using the `Or.inl` and `Or.inr` lemmas:
```lean
rw [List.append_nil] at h
exact Or.inr h
```
for the first one, and using `´Or.inl (full previous term)` for the second one.
Here as well.
Can you write tactics on separate lines please - there are a couple such instances in this file.

You can combine the last two tactic calls into one:
```suggestion
  obtain ⟨_, rfl⟩ := h
  exact (List.get_append _ _).symm
Can you follow the naming scheme of [add_right_eq_self](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Basic.html#add_right_eq_self), so `append_right_eq_self`?

```suggestion
  rw [← append_right_inj (t₁ := y), append_nil]
```
Can you also add the lemmas with `x ++ y = x` and `x = x ++ y` as LHS?

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem head_cons_tail (x : List α) (h : x ≠ []) : (x.head h) :: x.tail = x := by
```

These hypotheses are probably not the most convenient. How about assuming `∀ n < max l₁.length l₂.length, l₁.get? n = l₂.get? n` (as only assumption)?

Can you also add `iff` versions for this lemma?
This hypothesis was indeed nicer in my applications. I also added iff-versions for the other List ext lemmas, since they seemed to be missing

```suggestion
theorem IsPrefix.ne_nil {x y : List α} (hx : x ≠ []) (h : x <+: y) : y ≠ [] := by
```
to enable dot notation.
Since `h` is the hypothesis contains the `IsPrefix` assumption, should the order of hypotheses be changed, for `(h : x <+: y)` to come before `(hx : x ≠ [])`? (Similarly for the other two lemmas.)

Intuitively I'd prefer the current order, maybe just because in applications I used `apply ne_nil_prefix hx`. Moreover, dot notation would allow either `apply IsPrefix.ne_nil hx` or `apply h.ne_nil` with the current order, but only the second one (without _) with the suggested one. (Of course, there may be more relevant considerations)

Dot notation doesn't care about hypothesis order (to the extent that you are not swapping two `IsPrefix` assumptions).

I have a slight preference for having the order be `x <+: y → x ≠ [] → y ≠ []` so that you can get `h.ne_nil : x ≠ [] → y ≠ []`, but it's not a big deal.
I don't get it. Since dot notation doesn't care about hypothesis order, you get `h.ne_nil : x ≠ [] → y ≠ []` with either order, don't you?
It is less confusing if `h.ne_nil h2` is the same as `IsPrefix.ne_nil h h2` instead of `IsPrefix.ne_nil h2 h`. I also prefer the order `x <+: y → x ≠ [] → y ≠ []`, but I don't feel strongly.

```suggestion
theorem IsPrefix.get_eq {x y : List α} {n} (hn : n < x.length) (h : x <+: y) :
    x.get ⟨n, hn⟩ = y.get ⟨n, hn.trans_le h.length_le⟩ := by
```
I think it's good to keep large proof terms out of theorem *statements*
If Floris agrees above, I would suggest to also swap the order of the hypotheses `hn` and `h`; putting `h` first.

```suggestion
theorem IsPrefix.head_eq {x y : List α} (hx : x ≠ []) (h : x <+: y) :
```
(alternative name is `head_eq_of_isPrefix` following our naming conventions, but I think enabling the dot notation is nice.)
If Floris agrees above, I would suggest to also swap the order of the hypotheses `hn` and `h`; putting `h` first.

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem append_eq_right {x y : List α} : x ++ y = y ↔ x = [] := by
```
It's better not to rename variables across similar statements. Also avoid using both `left`/`right` and `self` as this usually leads to ambiguous names.
The current naming (suggested by Floris) is completely analogous to the one for `AddLeftCancelMonoid` (however, I will change the variable names)

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem right_eq_append {x y : List α} : y = x ++ y ↔ x = [] := by
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem append_eq_left {x y : List α} : x ++ y = x ↔ y = [] := by
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem left_eq_append {x y : List α} : x = x ++ y ↔ y = [] := by
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem head_cons_tail (x : List α) (h : x ≠ []) : x.head h :: x.tail = x := by
```

It's more readable (and usable) this way:
```suggestion
@[simp] theorem head_replicate (n : ℕ) (a : α) (h) : head (replicate n a) h = a := by
```

What's your motivation for these names? I would have expected something like
```suggestion
theorem ext_get? {l₁ l₂ : List α} (h' : ∀ n < max l₁.length l₂.length, l₁.get? n = l₂.get? n) :
    l₁ = l₂ := by
  apply ext
  intro n
  rcases Nat.lt_or_ge n <| max l₁.length l₂.length with hn | hn
  · exact h' n hn
  · simp_all [Nat.max_le, List.get?_eq_none.mpr]

theorem ext_get?_iff {l₁ l₂ : List α} : l₁ = l₂ ↔ ∀ n, l₁.get? n = l₂.get? n :=
  ⟨by rintro rfl _; rfl, List.ext⟩

theorem ext_get_iff' {l₁ l₂ : List α} : l₁ = l₂ ↔
    l₁.length = l₂.length ∧ ∀ n h₁ h₂, get l₁ ⟨n, h₁⟩ = get l₂ ⟨n, h₂⟩ := by
  constructor
  · rintro rfl
    exact ⟨rfl, fun _ _ _ ↦ rfl⟩
  · intro ⟨h₁, h₂⟩
    exact ext_get h₁ h₂

theorem ext_get?_iff' {l₁ l₂ : List α} : l₁ = l₂ ↔
    ∀ n < max l₁.length l₂.length, l₁.get? n = l₂.get? n :=
  ⟨by rintro rfl _ _; rfl, List.ext_get?⟩
```

My main reason is the naming of the existing non-iff versions. I previously added an alias List.ext_get? to List.ext, which is much closer to your suggestion, but had the impression that the consensus is to keep these names.
Personally I would have no idea what `List.ext` refers to if you asked me. What version of `get` is more fundamental? No idea

Personally I'm with you here (and I'm also annoyed by the fact that List.ext is marked @[ext] in Std). But just renaming the iff-lemmas seems worse than the current solution, and adding an alias without deprecating the old name also feels suboptimal. So, if we really want to change this, we should go via Std and not mathlib

> adding an alias without deprecating the old name also feels suboptimal

I actually have done this (along with a `-- TODO: Fix name in Std`) in the past, so I am willing to say this is the way forward.

Please avoid line breaks in the middle of a statement where possible, to improve readability
```suggestion
theorem ext_get_iff {l₁ l₂ : List α} :
    l₁ = l₂ ↔ l₁.length = l₂.length ∧ ∀ n h₁ h₂, get l₁ ⟨n, h₁⟩ = get l₂ ⟨n, h₂⟩ := by
```
Curious question: Can you easily deduce this by putting some `reverse` everywhere and applying `List.suffix_cons_iff`?
Indeed

```suggestion
  cases n <;> simp at h ⊢

```

Could you get a proof looking like this working?
```suggestion
  simpa using suffix_cons_iff (l₁ := x.reverse) (l₂ := y.reverse)
```
(Also this shows you probably shouldn't call your lists `x` and `y`)

Okay, this worked after adding a new lemma reverse_concat' (which seems to be good to have anyway as `x++[a]` seemingly is the simp-normal form of `x.concat a`. About the names: Is there a consistent convention? I think the mathlib naming convention mentioned s,t,... for lists, parts of the library use l_i, etc.
`s` , `t` for lists is quite strange. I use `a b c d w x y z : α`, `l l₁ l₂ : List α`, `L L₁ L₂ : List (List α)`, `m m₁ m₂ s s₁ s₂ t t₁ t₂ : Multiset α`, `s s₁ s₂ t t₁ t₂ u v : Finset α`.
Maybe in this case https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html should be updated
Yes, feel free to open a PR for that

```suggestion
theorem concat_get_prefix {x y : List α} (h : x <+: y) (hl : x.length < y.length) :
```

```suggestion
alias ext_get? := ext
```

```suggestion
theorem ext_get?_iff' {l₁ l₂ : List α} : l₁ = l₂ ↔
```
Can this go earlier?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: list lemmas

Thanks for your contribution and welcome to mathlib!

I gave your PR a first look and have a lot of style comments. (This is perfectly normed for a first PR.) Quite a few things are also copied from the [style guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html); did you get to read that already?

Some issues occur several times - I haven't mentioned them all the time; please also address similar instances below.

Thank you. I had a look at the style guide already, but my attempts to fix this with a few regexps didn't find all the issues. Now, apart from "hypotheses left of colon" (see above), I tried to fix all the mentioned issues

Thanks! You're right, the style guide doesn't mention spaces between tactics and their arguments. I think that's an oversight and should be fixed. (And I'll file a PR to remove the other occurrences.)

Just a few more, then I'm out of comments :-)

One more thing: when you're addressed a comment, can you click "resolve conversation"? (If you would still like some opinion on a question, just leave it open. But right now, it's hard to see which is which.) Thanks!

Also, please merge master because there is a merge conflict. Let me know if you need help / need me to do it.

LGTM
